prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 4C12.50_CO(1-0)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Our ALMA observation in Band 3 of this H2 luminous galaxy at the intersection of ULIRGs and young radio galaxies will probe the extent of the molecular gas in CO(1-0) and will be used in the determination of the excitation and temperature of the molecular gas.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The main science goal for this observation (for which the correlator has been set up) is to image the CO(1-0) emission. Our chosen band for the CO(1-0) is broad (5400 km/s bandwidth), but also includes spectral averaging to 11 km/s which is smaller than the requested 25 km/s and will allow sufficient resolution and bandwidth to allow for a baseline in the band to be taken and to detect and resolve different velocity strucutres should the line have a complex spatial distribution.
We include the CN line primarily as a detection experiment. The other correlator bands are set to detect 2.6mm continuum.

At the distance of 4C12.50, 0.45" corresponds to approximately 1 kpc resolution. Given the estimated size from the marginally resolved PdBI observation, this resolution will allow us to map the excitation and temperature of the molecular gas. Additionally, 4C12.50 is a merging system that has two clear nuclei (see Figure 2). With the requested resolution, ALMA will be able to determine whether each still has its own molecular disk. The approximate diameter of the system from the optical image is 12".

Figure 3 shows the CO(1-0) spectrum of 4C12.50 from the IRAM PdBI, which measured a total flux of 18.2 Jy km/s with a line width of 517 km/s, but only marginally resolved (Dasyra et al. 2014, A&A, 564, A46), suggesting a source radius of approximately 4 kpc (1.8" at the distance of 4C12.50). We used this size to calculate the brightness temperature of the CO(1-0) emission across the disk. We requested at least a S/N of 3 per 25 km/s channel, which will allow us to better differentiate between different kinematic components, such as a molecular outflow (e.g. Dasyra & Combes, 2012, A&A, 541, L7).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 4C12.50_CO(3-2)+870um
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Our ALMA observation in Band 7 of this H2 luminous galaxy at the intersection of ULIRGs and young radio galaxies will probe the extent of the molecular gas in CO(3-2) and will be used in the determination of the excitation and temperature of the molecular gas, as well as measuring the extent of the SF disk in the FIR.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The main science goal for this observation (for which the correlator has been set up) is to image the CO(3-2) emission as well as the 870um continuum. Our chosen band for the CO(3-2) is broad (1700 km/s bandwidth), but also includes spectral averaging to 7 km/s, smaller than the requested resolution across the line, allowing sufficient resolution and bandwidth to allow for a baseline in the band to be taken.
All other correlator bands are set to measure the 870um continuum emission - this is done to maximize the detection of the dust continuum's Rayleigh-Jeans tail, which we intend to use to accurately measure the extent of the star forming disk.

At the distance of 4C12.50, 0.45" corresponds to approximately 1 kpc resolution. Given the estimated size from the marginally resolved PdBI observation, this resolution will allow us to map the excitation and temperature of the molecular gas. Additionally, 4C12.50 is a merging system that has two clear nuclei (see Figure 2). With the requested resolution, ALMA will be able to determine whether each still has its own molecular disk. The approximate diameter of the system from the optical image is 12".

Figure 3 shows the CO(3-2) spectrum of 4C12.50 from the IRAM 30m, which measured a total flux of 50 Jy km/s with a line width of 510 km/s (Dasyra & Combes, 2012, A&A, 541, L7). The CO(1-0) PdBI observation suggests a source radius of approximately 4 kpc (1.8" at the distance of 4C12.50). We used this size to calculate the brightness temperature of the CO(3-2) emission across the disk. We requested at least a S/N of 3 per 25 km/s channel, which should allow to resolve the linewidth and search for kinematic components.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 4C12.50_CS(2-1)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Our ALMA observation in Band 3 of this H2 luminous galaxy at the intersection of ULIRGs and young radio galaxies will probe the dense gas tracer CS(2-1) to examine much shock-excitated CO may be overestimating the molecular mass.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The main science goal for this observation (for which the correlator has been set up) is to measure the CS(2-1) luminosity. Our chosen band for the CS(2-1) is broad (6400 km/s bandwidth), but also includes spectral averaging to 26 km/s that is smaller than the 50 km/s requested resolution that will allow us to determine whether the CS(2-1) line is as broad as the CO lines (500-600 km/s). The other correlator bands are set to detect continuum.

In the CS(2-1) line, we are primarily interested in getting a total luminosity in the dense gas tracer in order to compare the mass estimate from this tracer with that from CO. Therefore, we do not require as high a spatial resolution as for the CO observations in which we want to map the gas as well as its excitation. At the distance of 4C12.50, 2" corresponds to approximately 4 kpc resolution. The approximate diameter of the system from the optical image is 12".

Figure 3 shows the CO(1-0) spectrum of 4C12.50 from the IRAM PdBI, which measured a total flux of 18.2 Jy km/s with a line width of 517 km/s (Dasyra & Combes, 2012, A&A, 541, L7), but only marginally resolved, suggesting a source radius of approximately 4 kpc (1.8" at the distance of 4C12.50). We have assumed that the dense gas disk will have the same size and assumed that the intensity ratio between CO(1-0)/CS(2-1) is 20 (Baan et al. 2007, A&A, 477, 747; Meier et al. 2015, ApJ, 801, 63) to calculate the expected brightness temperature of CS(2-1) line of (54 mK). From this, we requested a signal-to-noise ratio of 3 per 50 km/s channel, so as to resolve the line.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 3C326N_CO(1-0)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Our ALMA observation in Band 3 of this H2 luminous galaxy with particularly strong jet-driven turblence will probe the extent of the molecular gas in CO(1-0) and will be used in the determination of the excitation and temperature of the molecular gas.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The main science goal for this observation (for which the correlator has been set up) is to image the CO(1-0) emission. Our chosen band for the CO(1-0) is broad (5300 km/s bandwidth), but also includes spectral averaging to 11 km/s which is smaller than the requested 25 km/s and will allow sufficient resolution and bandwidth to allow for a baseline in the band to be taken and to detect and resolve different velocity strucutres should the line have a complex spatial distribution.
We include the CN line primarily as a detection experiment. The other correlator bands are set to detect 2.6mm continuum.

At the distance of 3C326N, 0.6" corresponds to approximately 1 kpc resolution. Given the estimated size from the PdBI observation, this resolution will allow us to map the excitation and temperature of the molecular gas. The approximate major axis of this galaxy from the optical image (Figure 2) is 12".

Figure 3 shows the CO(1-0) spectrum of 3C326N from the IRAM PdBI, which measured a total flux of 1 Jy km/s with a line width of 350 km/s (Nesvadba et al. 2010, A&A, 521, A65). A more recent CO(2-1) observation estimated a source radius of 1.3" (~2 kpc at the distance of 3C326N; Labiano et al. 2013, A&A, 421, 461). We used this size to calculate the brightness temperature of the CO(1-0) emission across the disk. We requested at least a S/N of 3 per 25 km/s channel, which will allow us to search for kinematic signatures of a molecular component to the outflow driven by the radio-jet (Morganti et al. 2005, A&A, 444, L9).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 3C326N_CO(3-2)+870um
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Our ALMA observation in Band 7 of this H2 luminous galaxy with particularly strong jet-driven turblence will probe the extent of the molecular gas in CO(3-2) and will be used in the determination of the excitation and temperature of the molecular gas, as well as measuring the extent of the SF disk in the FIR.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The main science goal for this observation (for which the correlator has been set up) is to image the CO(3-2) emission as well as the 870um continuum. Our chosen band for the CO(3-2) is broad (1700 km/s bandwidth), but also includes spectral averaging to 7 km/s, smaller than the requested resolution across the line, allowing sufficient resolution and bandwidth to allow for a baseline in the band to be taken.
All other correlator bands are set to measure the 870um continuum emission - this is done to maximize the detection of the dust continuum's Rayleigh-Jeans tail, which we intend to use to accurately measure the extent of the star forming disk.

At the distance of 3C326N, 0.6" corresponds to approximately 1 kpc resolution. Given the estimated size from the PdBI observation, this resolution will allow us to map the excitation and temperature of the molecular gas. The approximate major axis of this galaxy from the optical image (Figure 2) is 12".

Figure 3 shows the CO(1-0) spectrum of 3C326N from the IRAM PdBI, which measured a total flux of 1 Jy km/s with a line width of 350 km/s (Nesvadba et al. 2010, A&A, 521, A65). A more recent CO(2-1) observation estimated a source radius of 1.3" (~2 kpc at the distance of 3C326N; Labiano et al. 2013, A&A, 421, 461). We used this size to calculate the brightness temperature of the CO(1-0) emission across the disk. From this, we assumed that the temperature ratio between CO(1-0)/CO(3-2) was 2 (Wilson et al. 2008, ApJS, 178, 189). We requested at least a S/N of 3 per 25 km/s channel, which should allow to resolve the linewidth.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 3C326N_CS(2-1)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Our ALMA observation in Band 3 of this H2 luminous galaxy with particularly strong jet-driven turblence will probe the dense gas tracer CS(2-1) to examine much shock-excitated CO may be overestimating the molecular mass.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The main science goal for this observation (for which the correlator has been set up) is to measure the CS(2-1) luminosity. Our chosen band for the CS(2-1) is broad (6200 km/s bandwidth), but also includes spectral averaging to 26 km/s that is smaller than the 50 km/s requested resolution that will allow us to determine whether the CS(2-1) line is as broad as the CO line (~350 km/s). The other correlator bands are set to detect continuum.

In the CS(2-1) line, we are primarily interested in getting a total luminosity in the dense gas tracer in order to compare the mass estimate from this tracer with that from CO. Therefore, we do not need to resolve this disk in the dense gas tracer at this time. The approximate major axis of this galaxy from the optical image (Figure 2) is 12".

Figure 3 shows the CO(1-0) spectrum of 3C326N from the IRAM PdBI, which measured a total flux of 1 Jy km/s with a line width of 350 km/s (Nesvadba et al. 2010, A&A, 521, A65). A more recent CO(2-1) observation estimated a source radius of 1.3" (~2 kpc at the distance of 3C326N; Labiano et al. 2013, A&A, 421, 461). We have assumed that the dense gas disk will have the same size and assumed that the intensity ratio between CO(1-0)/CS(2-1) is 20 (Baan et al. 2007, A&A, 477, 747; Meier et al. 2015, ApJ, 801, 63) to calculate the expected brightness temperature of CS(2-1) line of (13 mK). From this, we requested a signal-to-noise ratio of 3 per 50 km/s channel, so as to resolve the line.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Mrk668_CO(1-0)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Our ALMA observation in Band 3 of this H2 luminous galaxy with a bright AGN powering a neutral outflow will probe the extent of the molecular gas in CO(1-0) and will be used in the determination of the excitation and temperature of the molecular gas.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The main science goal for this observation (for which the correlator has been set up) is to image the CO(1-0) emission. Our chosen band for the CO(1-0) is broad (5200 km/s bandwidth), but also includes spectral averaging to 11 km/s which is smaller than the requested 25 km/s and will allow sufficient resolution and bandwidth to allow for a baseline in the band to be taken and to detect and resolve different velocity strucutres should the line have a complex spatial distribution.
We include the CN line primarily as a detection experiment. The other correlator bands are set to detect 2.6mm continuum.

At the distance of Mrk668, 0.34" corresponds to approximately 0.5 kpc resolution. Since Mrk668 does not currently have an estimated molecular disk size in the literature, we use the typical size from Diaz-Santos (2010, ApJ, 747, 95) of 1 kpc. Our requested resolution with provide multiple resolution elements across such a disk, allowing us to map the excitation and temperature of the molecular gas. The approximate semi-major axis of the galaxy from the optical image is 12" (Figure 2).

Figure 3 shows the CO(1-0) spectrum of Mrk668 from the IRAM 30m (as OQ+208), which measured a total flux of 11.9 Jy km/s with a line width of 400 km/s (Ocana-Flacquer et al. 2010, A&A, 521, A9). We assumed that the molecular gas was concentrated in a face-on disk with radius of 1 kpc (0.69" at the distance of Mrk668; Diaz-Santos, 2010, ApJ, 747, 95). We used this size to estimate the brightness temperature of the CO(1-0) emission across the disk. We requested at least a S/N of 3 per 25 km/s channel, which will allow us to better differentiate between different kinematic components.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Mrk668_CO(3-2)+870um
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Our ALMA observation in Band 7 of this H2 luminous galaxy with a bright AGN powering a neutral outflow will probe the extent of the molecular gas in CO(3-2) and will be used in the determination of the excitation and temperature of the molecular gas, as well as measuring the extent of the SF disk in the FIR.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The main science goal for this observation (for which the correlator has been set up) is to image the CO(3-2) emission as well as the 870um continuum. Our chosen band for the CO(3-2) is broad (1700 km/s bandwidth), but also includes spectral averaging to 7 km/s, smaller than the requested resolution across the line, allowing sufficient resolution and bandwidth to allow for a baseline in the band to be taken.
All other correlator bands are set to measure the 870um continuum emission - this is done to maximize the detection of the dust continuum's Rayleigh-Jeans tail, which we intend to use to accurately measure the extent of the star forming disk.

At the distance of Mrk668, 0.34" corresponds to approximately 0.5 kpc resolution. Since Mrk668 does not currently have an estimated molecular disk size in the literature, we use the typical size from Diaz-Santos (2010, ApJ, 747, 95) of 1 kpc. Our requested resolution with provide multiple resolution elements across such a disk, allowing us to map the excitation and temperature of the molecular gas. The approximate semi-major axis of the galaxy from the optical image is 12" (Figure 2).

Figure 3 shows the CO(1-0) spectrum of Mrk668 from the IRAM 30m (as OQ+208), which measured a total flux of 11.9 Jy km/s with a line width of 400 km/s (Ocana-Flacquer et al. 2010, A&A, 521, A9). We assumed that the molecular gas was concentrated in a face-on disk with radius of 1 kpc (0.69" at the distance of Mrk668; Diaz-Santos, 2010, ApJ, 747, 95). We used this size to estimate the brightness temperature of the CO(1-0) emission across the disk. From this, we assumed that the temperature ratio between CO(1-0)/CO(3-2) was 2 (Wilson et al. 2008, ApJS, 178, 189). We requested at least a S/N of 3 per 25 km/s channel, which should allow to resolve the linewidth.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Mrk668_CS(2-1)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Our ALMA observation in Band 3 of this H2 luminous galaxy with a bright AGN powering a neutral outflow will probe the dense gas tracer CS(2-1) to examine much shock-excitated CO may be overestimating the molecular mass.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The main science goal for this observation (for which the correlator has been set up) is to measure the CS(2-1) luminosity. Our chosen band for the CS(2-1) is broad (6100 km/s bandwidth), but also includes spectral averaging to 26 km/s that is smaller than the 50 km/s requested resolution that will allow us to determine whether the CS(2-1) line is as broad as the CO line (400 km/s). The other correlator bands are set to detect continuum.

In the CS(2-1) line, we are primarily interested in getting a total luminosity in the dense gas tracer in order to compare the mass estimate from this tracer with that from CO. Therefore, we do not need to resolve this disk in the dense gas tracer at this time. The approximate major axis of this galaxy from the optical image (Figure 2) is 12".

Figure 3 shows the CO(1-0) spectrum of Mrk668 from the IRAM 30m (as OQ+208), which measured a total flux of 11.9 Jy km/s with a line width of 400 km/s (Ocana-Flacquer et al. 2010, A&A, 521, A9). We assumed that the molecular gas was concentrated in a face-on disk with radius of 1 kpc (0.69" at the distance of Mrk668; Diaz-Santos, 2010, ApJ, 747, 95). We have assumed that the dense gas disk will have the same size and assumed that the intensity ratio between CO(1-0)/CS(2-1) is 20 (Baan et al. 2007, A&A, 477, 747; Meier et al. 2015, ApJ, 801, 63) to calculate the expected brightness temperature of CS(2-1) line of (110 mK). From this, we requested a signal-to-noise ratio of 3 per 50 km/s channel, so as to resolve the line.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
H2 luminous radio galaxies provide a key window into the suppression of star formation (SF) via turbulence injected into the interstellar medium by the radio jet. However, determining whether star formation is suppressed in these systems requires a thorough understanding of the state and extent of the molecular gas.
We propose ALMA observations to map three H2 luminous radio galaxies in CO(1-0), CO(3-2), CS(2-1), and 870 micron cold dust continuum in order to: 1) measure and the surface densities of SF activity and the molecular disk, 2) determine the excitation and temperature of the molecular gas, and 3) examine the kinematics of the molecular gas relative to the radio jet-driven outflows.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Infrared Processing and Analysis Center (IPAC), California Institute of Technology

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: The Carnegie Observatories, Carnegie Institution of Washington
Infrared Processing and Analysis Center (IPAC), California Institute of Technology
